title: Ticket #2936: CLAIM_PARTITIONABLE_LEFTOVERS=True segfaults
description:
We enabled a schedd that understands leftover claims and immediately started to segfault startd's left and right.

The stack dump looks like this: 

condor_startd(_ZN5Claim2idEv+0xb)[0x44102b]
condor_startd(_Z20accept_request_claimP8ResourceP5Claim+0x9d)[0x4356cd]
condor_startd(_Z13request_claimP8ResourceP5ClaimPcP6Stream+0xbeb)[0x43a35b]
condor_startd(_Z21command_request_claimP7ServiceiP6Stream+0x122)[0x43a9e2]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN10DaemonCore18CallCommandHandlerEiP6Streambbff+0x17e)[0x7f1268332a1e]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN21DaemonCommandProtocol11ExecCommandEv+0x50f)[0x7f12683386af]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN21DaemonCommandProtocol10doProtocolEv+0xe8)[0x7f1268339d28]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN21DaemonCommandProtocol14SocketCallbackEP6Stream+0x80)[0x7f1268339e40]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN10DaemonCore24CallSocketHandler_workerEibP6Stream+0x665)[0x7f1268333b95]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN10DaemonCore35CallSocketHandler_worker_demarshallEPv+0x1d)[0x7f1268333c6d]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN13CondorThreads8pool_addEPFvPvES0_PiPKc+0x40)[0x7f1268261670]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN10DaemonCore17CallSocketHandlerERib+0x147)[0x7f1268328e07]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_ZN10DaemonCore6DriverEv+0x2828)[0x7f126832bd08]
/usr/lib64/libcondor_utils_7_9_0.so(_Z7dc_mainiPPc+0x1312)[0x7f126833e4d2]

I was able to get this behavior to go away by setting:

CLAIM_PARTITIONABLE_LEFTOVERS=False

I can't get this version of Condor to dump a core, otherwise I'd be more useful. However, by the stack trace, it appears that the leftover_claim object is improperly initialized in request_claim - no other explanation as to why leftover_claim->id() would segfault.

2012-Apr-11 11:01:29 by bbockelm:
Reviewing the Claim::Id code, it looks like it would be very difficult to make it segfault by itself. Thus, it's possible there's other heap corruption issues going on elsewhere in the code. Maybe valgrind would reveal the culprit.

After 12 hours of CLAIM_PARTITIONABLE_LEFTOVERS=False, we've been running fairly stably. So, I think the issue is related to these code paths.

2012-May-04 14:01:10 by tannenba:
Looking things over, current theory is if the pslot is in owner state when the claim arrives, a seg fault happens as the transition from owner to unclaimed state invalidates the claim leftover's pointer to the pslot capability. Gonna test this out... patch looks like it may be very simple (fingers crossed)...

2012-May-04 16:15:12 by tannenba:
Indeed, the crash can be reproduced by setting 

    START = Owner =?= "tannenba"

and then submitting a job as tannenba that matches to a pslot. The above START expression results in the pslot being in Owner state (because it evals to False until a job is matched), and the crash happens when claiming a pslot that is in Owner state.

Reproduced crash before patch, verified it no longer crashes after patch. Patch pushed into V7_8_0-branch.

SLOT_TYPE_1_PARTITIONABLE = TRUE
START = Owner =?= "matt"

I am not seeing a crash.

I am seeing something I'm not familiar with in the SchedLog,

What's with the -1.-1 job match?

What are the specific reproduction instructions?

2012-May-07 08:48:59 by tannenba:
I have a couple ideas why you cannot reproduce the problem.

First off, you should be using code from V7_8_0-branch - who knows what else is going on with the master.

Second, re why you are not seeing a crash is because in startd ResState.cpp in enter_action(), there is code like: 

	case owner_state:
			// Always want to create new claim objects
		if( rip->r_cur ) {
			delete( rip->r_cur );
		}
		rip->r_cur = new Claim( rip );

This is the code snippet valgrid complained about. My guess is when you are running on your system, the newly created r_cur pointer is identical to the old r_cur pointer that was just deleted, and thus the crash is avoided! Perhaps this is one reason this bug was so sporadic. Would be nice if there was a way on debug builds to tell glibc to fill out deallocated memory regions with 0xDEADBEEF.

Assuming my guess is correct, repro instructions would be:

1. Patch as follows to help ensure a different region of memory is used (do not commit this patch) 

diff --git a/src/condor_startd.V6/ResState.cpp b/src/condor_startd.V6/ResState.cindex 8969e70..ef8e557 100644
--- a/src/condor_startd.V6/ResState.cpp
+++ b/src/condor_startd.V6/ResState.cpp
@@ -684,7 +684,15 @@ ResState::enter_action( State s, Activity a,
                if( rip->r_cur ) {
                        delete( rip->r_cur );
                }
+               {
+                       Claim *qqq1 = new Claim( rip );
+                       Claim *qqq2 = new Claim( rip );
+                       Claim *qqq3 = new Claim( rip );
                rip->r_cur = new Claim( rip );
+                       delete qqq1;
+                       delete qqq2;
+                       delete qqq3;
+               }
                if( rip->r_pre ) {
                        rip->remove_pre();
                }

2. Config condor as follows, so you end up with one pslot in owner state 

slot_type_1 = cpus=100%
num_slots_type_1 = 1
slot_type_1_partitionable = true
START=Owner=?="foo"

3. Submit matching job as owner foo, or whatever user you used in the START expression in the step above. Startd should crash during claiming step.

2012-May-07 11:35:13 by matt:
I've managed to repro on 0c43ecd (pre-patch). I didn't have SLOT_TYPE_1=cpus=100% in config. I think it's a bug that that is required, default should be cpus=auto and w/ one slot auto should be 100%.

This bug is NOT 100% reproducible. I'm getting about a 20% chance over 10 runs of submit + vacate_job + reschedule.

2012-May-07 11:51:57 by matt:
FYI, I'm reproducing with, 

$ tail config.d/50mef.config
ALL_DEBUG = D_FULLDEBUG
SLOT_TYPE_1 = cpus=100%
#NUM_SLOTS = 1
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1 = 1
SLOT_TYPE_1_PARTITIONABLE = TRUE
START = Owner =?= "matt"
#START = TRUE

$ echo 'cmd=/bin/sleep\nargs=1d\nqueue 2' | condor_submit

$ count=0; while [ true ]; do echo "run $count"; condor_vacate_job 1 ; sleep 10 ; condor_reschedule ; sleep 10 ; condor_q; count=$((count+1)); done

Post-patch I'm up to 20 runs without a crash.

2012-May-07 12:11:20 by matt:
I ran the repro instructions to count=75 for a 5bf288a build (post-patch). No crashes.

2012-May-07 12:22:31 by matt:
CODE REVIEW This looks good to me. I'm still uneasy about the fragility of the state machine, but that should be addressed outside this bug.
